bibl.title: Letter from R.S. Galbreath to Philip Showalter Hench, August 16, 1941

div1.p: Galbreath comments on John Kissinger's medical condition and Ida Kissinger's personality.

div1.head: Letter from R.S. Galbreath to Philip Showalter Hench, August 16, 1941
div1.opener:
OFFICE PHONE 32
RES. PHONE 2007
R. S. GALBREATH, M. D.
OFFICE 16 WEST WASHINGTON STREET
HUNTINGTON, INDIANA
Aug. 16, 1941
P.S. Hench M.D.
The Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor Hench:-
div1.p:
Your first letter arrived
while I was on a little vacation and it seemed I was swamped for
a while and the rest was gross neglect, in answering your letter.

No matter how big we try to be, we still have
some things that stick in our systems that we can't forget. I treated
Kissingers at Andrews when they were down and out, and no
recognition had ever been made of his feat. He made the remark
to my father once that I was the first doctor that hadn't charged him
anything. I was instrumental in getting him his present home and
pension, through my second cousin S.M. Keltner of Anderson, et al.

Since he came into prominance, while he is
a child of the medical world, he has devoted all of his interests
to chiropractic, and they only called me after the chiropractor was
satisfied that he was going to die.

We might finish Mrs. Kissinger before discussing
John. She is nervous and jittery, but I think able to do all of the
work that John requires. I think she is the type that would accept
all that was offered her, and would graciously say “thanks” would feel
that the giver owed it to her. I have been furnishing all of the
medicine, and they don't offer to send for it, and I pay the taxi to
take it up to them.

Congress bought him his present home, and
allowed him a pension for life. I don't know how much, but imagine it
was sufficient for them to live on. So much for the side slant on the
personal side.

Mr. Kissinger is much better. Up and around the
house, sits on the porch and talks rather intelligently. Blood pressure
about normal and kidneys Neg.

While he had what we termed a stroke, there was
something peculiar about it. I am not enough of a neurologist to
make a diagnosis, but the mental side was predominant. He didn't know
anything, couldn't talk, laid in bed and responded poorly to everything,
and retained the use of his limbs, although there was marked weakness
on the one side.

Do not believe there would be any use in sending
him to a hospital, even if he gets worse, and certainly not now. Have
a feeling if he gets another attack that he will die in a short time,
and that there is no treatment that will help much. If he continues to
improve as he has in the last few weeks, he will be in fair condition,
although his mentality is far from normal.

I hope this answers some of the questions in
laymans terms. If things get to where something has to be done, I will
call on you. Apologizing again for the delay in answering your
letter, I am yours
